awd_titl_txt: Forbidding Induced Subgraphs: Structure and Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to study a number of well-known open problems in graph theory, as well as new problems suggested by them. The proposed questions are all related to the study of graphs with certain forbidden substructures. The line of inquiry that guides the research is: what is the global difference between general graphs and graphs that do not contain a particular substructure?  These problems have been open for a while, but the PI and her collaborators have recently made progress on most of them. It is only now that a global picture is coming to light, and it seems likely that methods used for some of the problems can carry over to others. Exploring this crossover of ideas will undoubtedly lead to the development of new methods and approaches that were too far out of reach before, and are likely to allow further exciting developments.

The focus of the project is on the influence of excluding an induced subgraph (or a family of them) on the structure of a graph.  Specifically the PI and her collaborators  plan to explore the following aspects to this question: the connections between the clique number and the chromatic number, the complexity of the graph coloring problem, the structure of minimal obstructions to colorability, the presence in a graph of large tightly structured subgraphs (the Erdos-Hajnal conjecture and its variants), and more.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to study how the behavior of a graph changes when certain configurations (called "induced subgraphs") are excluded from it. More broadly  this falls into the framework of the study of local/global phenomena.
Several aspects of the question where addressed: the existence of efficient algorithms, the behavior of natural graph parameters, and the presence in the graph of certain "well-structured" sets. Important progress was made on all the aspects and a number of long-standing open problems have been resolved. The results were presented at major international conferences and submitted for publication to top-notch journals in the field. Much of the work was done jointly with students and post-docs, thus contributing to education and workforce training.

The PI is a popular speaker for public/general interest lectures, where she
is able to disseminate and popularize her work, and the field in general.
She appeared on the Numberphile YouTube channel attracting over a quarter million viewers. She is actively involved  in several projects encouraging young
women to pursue careers in mathematics and other STEM fields.
She is a member of the organizing committee for the IAS Women and Math program (in Princeton), she delivered multiple lectures in events related to promting women in mathematics,   and participated in a number of panels  and interviews.


Last Modified: 10/29/2022
Modified by: Maria Chudnovsky
